comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content:
That was a Leyland Atlantean demonstrator vehicle, fitted with a Metro-Cammell-Weymann (MCW) body. It went on to serve with four different operators including Lough Swilly. Sadly, although preserved at one stage, it was later scrapped.

I'd suggest that the picture was in fact taken outside CIE HQ on O'Connell Street, and the gentlemen shown were almost certainly top brass of the company at that time, evaluating the vehicle. But it was another 7 years before the large batch of what eventually became 640 Atlanteans started to arrive into Dublin and elsewhere in Ireland.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/apl-irl] Thanks for the invaluable technical information! About the location, I'd argue that this was taken outside what is now Clarks/Eason's, and the CIE HQ was much further down O'Connell Street. Have a look at this Streetview - not the precise angle, but there are the buildings at each corner of Lower Abbey Street and O'Connell Street that can just be made out between the lamp post and the front of the bus in this photo...

comment.author: 76509678@N04
comment._content: Built just down the road from me in Leyland, Lancashire, England. I may even know some of the men who built it, a guy called Joe Delaney who worked for Leyland motors from the late forties to the seventies. He worked on that range of buses (when he wasn't on strike lol).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/76509678@N04] :D  Is Joe Delaney still with us?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 76509678@N04
comment._content: Unfortunately not, he passed awsy in 2005.  He's not forgotten though, I am good friends with his son Kevin and we often raise a glass. There's still a old brazier from one of the Leyland picket lines in Kev's back garden.  I am sure Leyland were on strike more than they actually worked in the 70s, that's due to bad management as well as militancy.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: The same vehicle - many years later. It was demonstrated to CIE, Belfast Corporation and the Ulster Transport Authority and its' effect was to shape CIE Dublin bus buying policy for many years to come. As others have said, it eventually ended up at Lough Swilly before an attempt was made to preserve it but it was sadly scrapped. A great loss to Irish transport history! <a

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: and the Blackpool Olympian is relevant.....how? have i missed something here?

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: Lots of ex Dublin Olympians have gone onto new lives in the UK and elsewhere in Ireland. Of the 600 only 51 still remain in service today in Dublin, and that number is set to reduce when the new batch of 80 Wright's Gemini tri-axles arrive shortly!

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content:
An interesting but unfortunate further anecdote to the overall story of buses coming to Dublin for trials and then going on elsewhere has to be the one about Dublin Bus fleet number WH1, those letters stood for Wright's Hybrid 1. Up until fairly recently you would have seen this vehicle going about the city very regularly, it looked like a lot of the other Wright Gemini buses but had the diesel electric hybrid engine fitted, a Ford 2.4 litre example.......

This year it got sold to Ensignbus in the UK for further use elsewhere and was repainted into their livery....

All was going fine until last Sunday, when this happened:- 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/33747326@N05/7361237054/in/contacts/]
